<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Assets
for the Executives Plan consist of deposits on hand with regulatory authorities which are refundable when benefit payments are made or on the ultimate wind-up of the plan. The
accumulated benefit obligation for this plan at December&nbsp;31, 2009 was $6.4&nbsp;million (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$4.5&nbsp;million). At the end of 2009, the remaining
unamortized net transition obligation was $0.8&nbsp;million (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$0.8&nbsp;million) for the Executives Plan and the net transition asset was nil
(2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$0.1&nbsp;million) for the Employees&nbsp;Plan. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
addition to the Employees Plan and the Executives Plan, the Company has two defined contribution pension plans. Under the basic plan (the&nbsp;"Basic Plan"), Agnico-Eagle contributes 5% of each
employee's base employment compensation to a defined </FONT></P>

</UL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>24</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=24,EFW="2197667",CP="AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED",DN="4",CHK=253974,FOLIO='24',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAH3.10ZAH79303]FI79303A.;39',USER='JDAY',CD='26-MAR-2010;15:10' -->
<A NAME="page_fi79303_1_25"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (thousands of United States dollars, except per share amounts, unless otherwise indicated)<BR>
December 31, 2009 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;RECLAMATION PROVISION AND OTHER LIABILITIES (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>contribution
plan. The expense in 2009 was $6.5&nbsp;million (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$5.3&nbsp;million; 2007&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$4.3&nbsp;million). In
addition to the Basic Plan, effective January&nbsp;1, 2008 the Company adopted the supplemental plan for designated executives at the level of
Vice-President or above. Under this plan, an additional 10% of the designated executives' earnings for the year (including salary and short-term bonus) are contributed by the
Company. In 2009, $0.9&nbsp;million (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$0.7&nbsp;million) was contributed to the supplemental&nbsp;plan. </FONT></P>

</UL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SHAREHOLDERS' EQUITY  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>(a)</I></B></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>Common shares</I></B></FONT></DD></DL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company's authorized capital stock includes an unlimited number of common shares with issued common shares of 156,655,056 (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;154,808,918), less
29,882&nbsp;treasury shares related to the restricted share unit plan (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;nil). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
2009, the Company declared dividends on its common shares of $0.18 per share (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$0.18 per share;
2007&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$0.18&nbsp;per&nbsp;share).  </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>(b)</I></B></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>Flow-through common share private placements</I></B></FONT></DD></DL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
2009, Agnico-Eagle issued 358,900 (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;779,250; 2007&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;nil) common shares under flow-through share private
placements that increased share capital by $19.2&nbsp;million (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$43.5&nbsp;million; 2007&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;nil), net of share
issue costs. Effective December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company renounced to its investors C$30.6&nbsp;million (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;C$54.5&nbsp;million;
2007&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;C$10.1&nbsp;million) of such expenses for income tax purposes. The Company does not have an obligation to incur any exploration expenditures related to
the expenditures previously renounced. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
difference between the flow-through share issuance price and the market price of Agnico-Eagle's shares at the time of purchase is recorded as a liability at the time the
flow-through shares are issued. This liability terminates when the exploration expenditures are renounced to investors. The difference between the flow-through share issuance
price and market price reduces the future tax expense charged to income as this difference represents proceeds received by the Company for the sale of future tax deductions to investors in the
flow-through shares.  </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>(c)</I></B></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>Private placements</I></B></FONT></DD></DL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>On
December&nbsp;3, 2008, the Company closed a private placement of 9.2&nbsp;million units. Each unit consisted of one common share and one-half of one common share purchase warrant.
Each whole warrant entitles the holder to purchase one common share of the Company at a price of $47.25 per share at any time during the five-year term of the warrant. As consideration for
the lead purchaser's commitment, the Company issued to the lead purchaser an additional 4&nbsp;million warrants. The net proceeds of the private placement were approximately $281&nbsp;million,
after deducting share issue costs of $8.8&nbsp;million. If all outstanding warrants are exercised, the Company would issue an additional 8.6&nbsp;million common&nbsp;shares. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>On
May&nbsp;26, 2009, the Company issued 15,825&nbsp;shares with a market value of $0.9&nbsp;million in connection with the acquisition of a 100% participating interest in 52&nbsp;mining
claims, located in the Abitibi region of&nbsp;Quebec. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>On
July&nbsp;24, 2009, the Company issued 18,000&nbsp;shares for consideration of $500 in connection with the exercise of an option granted by a predecessor to the Company relating to the
acquisition of certain properties relating to the Goldex&nbsp;Mine.  </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>(d)</I></B></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>Public offering of common shares</I></B></FONT></DD></DL>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
December&nbsp;2008, the Company issued 900,000&nbsp;shares at a price of $38 per share under a prospectus supplement to its base shelf prospectus to fund a purchase of surface rights and
advance royalty payments in connection with the development of the Pinos Altos property. The net proceeds of the issuance were approximately $34.2&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>There
were no public offerings of common shares in 2009.  </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>(e)</I></B></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>Accumulated other comprehensive income (loss)</I></B></FONT></DD></DL>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
cumulative translation adjustment in accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) in 2009 and 2008 of $(15.9) million resulted from Agnico-Eagle electing the US dollar as its principal currency
of measurement. Prior to this change, the Canadian dollar had been used as the reporting currency. Prior periods' consolidated financial statements were translated into US dollars by the current rate
method using the year end or the annual average exchange rate where appropriate. This translation approach was </FONT></P>

</UL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>25</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

December 31, 2009 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SHAREHOLDERS' EQUITY (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>applied
from January&nbsp;1, 1994. This translation gave rise to a deficit in the cumulative translation adjustment account within accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) as at
December&nbsp;31, 2009 and&nbsp;2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company has designated certain foreign exchange derivative contracts as cash flow hedges and, as such, unrealized gains and losses on these contracts are recorded in accumulated other
comprehensive&nbsp;income&nbsp;(loss). </FONT></P>

following table sets out the components of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss), net of related tax&nbsp;effects: </FONT></P>

<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
calculation of diluted income per share has been computed using the treasury stock method. In applying the treasury stock method, options and warrants with an exercise price greater than the
average quoted market price, for the period outstanding, of the common shares are not included in the calculation of diluted income per share as the effect is anti-dilutive. </FONT></P>

</UL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;STOCK-BASED COMPENSATION  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>(a)</I></B></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>Employee Stock Option Plan ("ESOP")</I></B></FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company's ESOP provides for the granting of options to directors, officers, employees and service providers to purchase common shares. Under this plan, options are granted at the fair market value
of the underlying shares on the day prior to the date of grant. The number of shares subject to option for any one person may not exceed 5% of the Company's common shares issued and outstanding at the
date of&nbsp;grant. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Up
to May&nbsp;31, 2001, the number of common shares reserved for issuance under the ESOP was 6,000,000 and options granted under the ESOP had a maximum term of ten years. On April&nbsp;24, 2001,
the Compensation Committee of the Board of Directors adopted a policy pursuant to which options granted after that date shall have a maximum term of five years. In 2001, the shareholders approved a
resolution to increase the number of common shares reserved for issuance under the ESOP by 2,000,000 to 8,000,000. In 2004 and 2006, the shareholders approved a further 2,000,000 and
3,000,000&nbsp;common shares for issuance under the ESOP, respectively. In 2008, the shareholders approved a further 6,000,000&nbsp;common shares for issuance under the&nbsp;ESOP. </FONT></P>

</UL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>26</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=26,EFW="2197667",CP="AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED",DN="4",CHK=71385,FOLIO='26',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAH3.10ZAH79303]FI79303B.;68',USER='JDAY',CD='26-MAR-2010;15:10' -->
<A NAME="page_fi79303_1_27"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (thousands of United States dollars, except per share amounts, unless otherwise indicated)<BR>
December 31, 2009 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;STOCK-BASED COMPENSATION (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Of
the 2,276,000&nbsp;options granted under the ESOP in 2009, 569,000&nbsp;options granted vested immediately and expire in 2014. The remaining options expire in 2014 and vest in equal
installments, on each anniversary date of the grant, over a three-year period. Of the 2,549,400&nbsp;options granted under the ESOP in 2008, 637,350&nbsp;options granted vested
immediately and expire in 2013. The remaining options expire in 2013 and vest in equal installments, on each anniversary date of the grant, over a three-year period. Of the
1,380,000&nbsp;options granted under the ESOP in 2007, 345,000&nbsp;options granted vested immediately and expire in 2012. The remaining options expire in 2012 and vest in equal installments, on
each anniversary date of the grant, over a three-year period. As a result of the acquisition of Cumberland Resources&nbsp;Ltd. ("Cumberland"), 326,250&nbsp;options in Cumberland were
converted to options of the Company. All these options vested immediately. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Upon
the exercise of stock options under the ESOP, the Company issues new common shares to settle the obligation. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
following summary sets out the activity with respect to Agnico-Eagle's outstanding stock&nbsp;options: </FONT></P>
</UL>
</UL>

<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Cash
received for options exercised in 2009 was $36.6&nbsp;million (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$33.6&nbsp;million;
2007&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$8.8&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
total intrinsic value of options exercised in 2009 was C$43.8&nbsp;million (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;C$50.5&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
weighted average grant-date fair value of options granted in 2009 was C$24.52 (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;C$16.78;
2007&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;C$12.53). The following table summarizes information about Agnico-Eagle's stock options outstanding at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2009: </FONT></P>
</UL>
</UL>
<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR><!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS SET -->
<TD WIDTH="32" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="127" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="12" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="4" ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"></TD>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
weighted-average remaining contractual term of options exercisable at December&nbsp;31, 2009, was 2.6&nbsp;years. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company has reserved for issuance 5,707,940&nbsp;common shares in the event that these options are&nbsp;exercised. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
number of un-optioned shares available for granting of options as at December&nbsp;31, 2009, 2008 and 2007 was 4,155,750, 6,349,250 and 2,832,250, respectively. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>On
January&nbsp;4, 2010, 2,735,080&nbsp;options were granted under the ESOP, of which 683,770&nbsp;options vested immediately and expire in the year 2015. The remaining options expire in 2015
and vest in equal installments on each anniversary date of the grant, over a three-year period. </FONT></P>

<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company uses historical volatility in estimating the expected volatility of Agnico-Eagle's share&nbsp;price. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
aggregate intrinsic value of options outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2009 was C$17.5&nbsp;million. The aggregate intrinsic value of options exercisable at December&nbsp;31, 2009 was
C$21.4&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
total compensation expense for the ESOP recognized in the consolidated statements of income for the current year was $27.7&nbsp;million
(2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$25.3&nbsp;million; 2007&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$9.8&nbsp;million). The total compensation cost related to non-vested
options not yet recognized was $33.3&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2009. Of the total compensation cost for the ESOP, $8.7&nbsp;million was capitalized as part of construction costs in
2009 (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$9.0&nbsp;million; 2007&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;nil).  </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>(b)</I></B></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>Incentive Share Purchase Plan</I></B></FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>On
June&nbsp;26, 1997, the shareholders approved an incentive share purchase plan (the&nbsp;"Purchase Plan") to encourage directors, officers and employees ("Participants") to purchase
Agnico-Eagle's common shares at market&nbsp;values. In 2009, the Purchase Plan was amended to remove non-executive directors as eligible participants in the plan </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Under
the Purchase Plan, Participants may contribute up to 10% of their basic annual salaries, and the Company contributes an amount equal to 50% of each Participant's contribution. All shares
subscribed for under the Purchase Plan are newly issued by the Company. The total compensation cost recognized in 2009 related to the Purchase Plan was $3.8&nbsp;million
(2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$3.2&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
2009, 196,649&nbsp;common shares were subscribed for under the Purchase Plan (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;154,998; 2007&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;167,378) for a
value of $11.3&nbsp;million (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$9.5&nbsp;million; 2007&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$7.1&nbsp;million). In May&nbsp;2008, shareholders
approved an increase in the maximum number of shares reserved for issuance under the Purchase Plan to 5,000,000&nbsp;from 2,500,000. As at
December&nbsp;31, 2009, Agnico-Eagle has reserved for issuance 2,740,504&nbsp;common shares (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;2,937,153;
2007&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;592,151) under the Purchase&nbsp;Plan.  </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>(c)</I></B></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>Restricted Share Unit Plan</I></B></FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
2009, the Company implemented a restricted share unit ("RSU") plan for certain employees. A deferred compensation balance was recorded for the total grant-date value on the date of the
grant. The deferred compensation balance was recorded as a reduction of shareholders' equity and is being amortized as compensation expense (or&nbsp;capitalized to construction in progress) over the
applicable vesting period of two&nbsp;years. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company funded the plan by transferring $3.0&nbsp;million to an employee benefit trust (the&nbsp;"Trust") that then purchased shares of the Company in the open market. Compensation costs for
RSUs incorporates an expected forfeiture rate. The forfeiture rate is estimated based on the Company's historical employee turnover rates and expectations of future forfeiture rates that incorporate
various factors that include historical employee stock option plan forfeiture rates. For 2009, the impact of forfeitures was not material. For accounting purposes, the Trust is treated as a VIE and
consolidated in the accounts of the Company. On consolidation, the dividends paid on the shares held by the Trust are eliminated. The shares purchased and held by the Trust are treated as not being
outstanding for the basic earnings per share ("EPS") calculations. They are amortized back into basic EPS over the vesting period. All of the shares held by the Trust were included in the diluted EPS
calculations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Compensation
cost related to the RSUs was $1.5&nbsp;million in 2009, with $0.3&nbsp;million being capitalized to Property, Plant and Mine Development line item in the consolidated balance sheets.
The $1.2&nbsp;million of compensation expense is included as a component of production, administration and exploration expense, consistent with the classification of other elements of compensation
expense for those employees who had RSUs. </FONT></P>

</UL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>28</FONT></P>

<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Cash
income and mining taxes paid in 2009 were $8.8&nbsp;million (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$3.8&nbsp;million;
2007&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$22.1&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

income and mining taxes recovery is different from the amount that would have been computed by applying the Canadian statutory income tax rate as a result of the&nbsp;following: </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>All
of Agnico-Eagle's future income tax assets and liabilities were denominated in local currency based on the jurisdiction in which the Company paid taxes and were translated into US dollars using
the exchange rate in effect at the consolidated balance sheet dates. The increase in future income tax liabilities was due in part to the weaker US dollar in relation to the Canadian dollar. On
December&nbsp;12, 2008 however, the Company executed a Canadian federal tax election to commence using the US dollar as its functional currency for federal Canadian income tax purposes. This
election applies to taxation years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and subsequent. This election resulted in a deferred tax benefit of $21.0&nbsp;million for the period ended
December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2009. At December&nbsp;31, 2009, asset and liability amounts were translated into US dollars at an exchange rate of C$1.0466 per $1.00, and at an exchange rate of
SEK&nbsp;7.2125&nbsp;per $1.00, whereas at December&nbsp;31, 2008, asset and liability amounts were translated at an exchange rate of C$1.2240 per $1.00, and at an exchange rate of SEK
7.8770&nbsp;per&nbsp;$1.00. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company operates in different jurisdictions and accordingly it is subject to income and other taxes under the various tax regimes in the countries in which it operates. The tax rules and
regulations in many countries are highly complex and subject to interpretation. The Company may be subject in the future to a review of its historic income and other tax filings and in connection with
such reviews, </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
full amount of unrecognized tax benefits of $5,608, if recognized, would reduce the Company's annual effective tax rate. The Company does not expect its unrecognized tax benefits to change
significantly over the next 12&nbsp;months. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company is subject to taxes in the following significant jurisdictions: Canada, Mexico, Sweden and Finland, each with varying statutes of limitations. The 1999 through 2009 tax years generally
remain subject to&nbsp;examination. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 9.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ACQUISITIONS  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>Cumberland Resources&nbsp;Ltd.</I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>On
February&nbsp;14, 2007, the Company and Agnico-Eagle Acquisition Corporation ("Agnico Acquisition"), a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, signed an agreement with Cumberland under which the
Company and Agnico Acquisition agreed to make an exchange offer (the&nbsp;"Offer") for all of the outstanding common shares of Cumberland not already owned by the Company. At the time, the Company
owned 2,037,000 or 2.6% of the outstanding shares of Cumberland on a fully diluted basis. Under the terms of the Offer, each Cumberland share was to be exchanged for 0.185&nbsp;common shares of
Agnico-Eagle. At the time, Cumberland owned 100% of the Meadowbank gold project, located in Nunavut, Canada. As of July&nbsp;9, 2007, all common shares of Cumberland were acquired pursuant to the
Offer. As of July&nbsp;9, 2007, a total of 13,768,510 of the Company's shares were issued for the acquisition resulting in an increase of $536.6&nbsp;million in common shares issued. The total
purchase price as of July&nbsp;9, 2007 amounted to $577.0&nbsp;million which was allocated to various balance sheet accounts, mainly mining properties. On August&nbsp;1, 2007, Agnico
Acquisition, Cumberland and a wholly-owned subsidiary of Cumberland were amalgamated with Agnico-Eagle. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
results of operations of Cumberland are included in the income statement for the combined entity from April&nbsp;17,&nbsp;2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
purchase price paid through the issuance of 13,768,510&nbsp;shares of the Company is summarized as&nbsp;follows. </FONT></P>
</UL>

<TD style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:8pt;text-indent:-8pt;"><FONT SIZE=1> </FONT><FONT SIZE=1>Total shares issued</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TR style="font-size:1.5pt;" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
addition, the Company entered into a series of gold derivative transactions in connection with the take-over bid for Cumberland in February&nbsp;2007. Prior to announcement of the
take-over bid by Agnico-Eagle, Cumberland secured a gold loan facility for up to 420,000&nbsp;ounces. As part of the condition of the gold loan, Cumberland entered into a series of
derivative transactions to secure a minimum monetized value for the gold that was expected to be received under the gold loan. Cumberland entered into a zero-cost collar whereby a gold put
option was bought with a strike price of C$605 per ounce. The cost of the put option was financed by the sale of a gold call option with a strike price of $800 per ounce. Both of Cumberland's
derivative positions were for 420,000&nbsp;ounces of gold and matured on September&nbsp;20, 2007, the expected drawdown date of the loan. As Agnico-Eagle's policy is to not sell forward gold
production, Agnico-Eagle entered into a series of transactions to neutralize Cumberland's derivative position. Accordingly, Agnico-Eagle purchased call options and sold put options with the exact same
size, strike price and maturity as Cumberland's derivative position for $15.9&nbsp;million. All derivative positions were closed out in late June&nbsp;2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>During
2008 certain tax assets that were not recognized upon the acquisition of Cumberland in 2007 were determined to be more likely than not to be realized. This resulted in a decrease to mineral
properties and the future income tax liability of $15&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>30</FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Other
liabilities mainly consists of the liability portion of the flow-through shares issuance of $6.8&nbsp;million (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$17.5&nbsp;million)
(note&nbsp;6(b)). </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 11.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Contact
Diamond Corporation ("Contact") was a consolidated entity of the Company for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. As of August&nbsp;2003, the Company ceased consolidating Contact as the
Company's investment no longer represented a "controlling financial interest". The loan was originally advanced for the purpose of funding ongoing exploration and operating activities. The loan was
repayable on demand with a rate of interest on the loan of 8% per annum. The Company, however, waived the interest on this loan commencing May&nbsp;13,&nbsp;2002. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
2006, the Company tendered its 13.8&nbsp;million Contact shares in conjunction with Stornoway Diamond Corporation's ("Stornoway") offer to acquire all of the outstanding shares of Contact. Under
the terms of the offer, each share of Contact was exchanged for 0.36 of a Stornoway share resulting in the receipt by the Company of 4,968,747&nbsp;Stornoway shares. A $4.4&nbsp;million gain on
the exchange of shares was recognized and a gain of $2.9&nbsp;million was recognized on the write-up of the loan to Contact during 2006. On February&nbsp;12, 2007, Agnico-Eagle
subscribed to a private placement of subscription receipts by Stornoway for a total cost of $19.8&nbsp;million. Stornoway acquired the debt in full by way of assignment of the note in consideration
for the issuance to the Company of 3,207,861&nbsp;common shares of Stornoway at a deemed value of C$1.25 per share. In addition, on March&nbsp;16, 2007, the Company purchased from Stornoway
C$5&nbsp;million in unsecured Series&nbsp;A Convertible Debentures and C$5&nbsp;million in unsecured Series&nbsp;B Convertible Debentures. Both series of debentures matured two years after
their date of issue and interest was payable under the debentures quarterly at 12% per annum. At the option of Stornoway, interest payments could be paid in cash or in shares of Stornoway. During
2008, the interest payments to the Company amounted to C$0.7&nbsp;million and consisted of 1,940,614&nbsp;shares (2007&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;C$0.9&nbsp;million of which
C$0.6&nbsp;million was received in cash and the rest 302,450&nbsp;shares) of&nbsp;Stornoway. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>31</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=13,SEQ=31,EFW="2197667",CP="AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED",DN="4",CHK=754007,FOLIO='31',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAH3.10ZAH79303]FI79303B.;68',USER='JDAY',CD='26-MAR-2010;15:10' -->
<A NAME="page_fi79303_1_32"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (thousands of United States dollars, except per share amounts, unless otherwise indicated)<BR>
December 31, 2009 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 11.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>On
July&nbsp;31, 2008, the Company purchased from treasury 12,222,222&nbsp;common shares of Stornoway at a price of C$0.90 per common share. Stornoway used the proceeds of the private placement to
redeem the C$10&nbsp;million principal amount of convertible debentures held by the Company and to pay to the Company a C$1&nbsp;million amendment fee in connection with the amendment of the
debentures to permit early redemption. The Company received an additional 527,947&nbsp;common shares of Stornoway in satisfaction of accrued but unpaid interest on the debentures prior to their
redemption. As a result of these transactions, the Company increased its holdings in Stornoway from 27,520,809&nbsp;common shares (approximately 13.6% of the issued and outstanding common shares) to
40,270,978&nbsp;common shares (approximately 15.8% of the issued and outstanding common&nbsp;shares). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Agnico-Eagle's
holdings in Stornoway as at December&nbsp;31, 2009 remain unchanged at 40,270,978&nbsp;common shares (approximately 15.3% of the issued and outstanding common&nbsp;shares). </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Subsequent
to year-end, the Company purchased 5.0&nbsp;million common shares of Stornoway at a price of C$0.50&nbsp;per common share. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 12.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;COMMITMENTS AND CONTINGENCIES  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>As
part of its ongoing business and operations, the Company has been required to provide assurance in the form of letters of credit for environmental and site restoration costs, custom credits,
government grants and other general corporate purposes. As at December&nbsp;31, 2009, the total amount of these guarantees was $85.3&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Certain
of the Company's properties are subject to royalty arrangements. The following are the most significant royalties. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company has a royalty agreement with the Finnish government relating to the Kittila Mine. Starting 12&nbsp;months after the mining operations commence, the Company has to pay 2% on net smelter
return, defined as revenue less processing costs. The royalty is paid on a yearly basis the following&nbsp;year. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company is committed to pay a royalty on future production from the Meadowbank Mine. The Nunavut Tunngavik-administered mineral claims are subject to production leases including a 12% net profits
interest royalty from which annual deductions are limited to 85% of gross revenue. Production from Crown mining leases is subject to a royalty of up to 14% of adjusted net profits, as defined in the </FONT> <FONT SIZE=1><I>Northwest Territories and
Nunavut Mining Regulations</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=1> under the </FONT><FONT SIZE=1><I>Territorial Lands Act</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;(Canada). </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company is committed to pay a royalty on production from properties in the Abitibi area. The type of royalty agreements include but are not limited to net profits interest royalty and net smelter
return royalty with percentages ranging from 0.5% to&nbsp;5%. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company is committed to pay a royalty on production from properties in the Pinos Altos area. The type of royalty agreements include but are not limited to net profits interest royalty and net
smelter return royalty with percentages ranging from 2.5% to&nbsp;3.5%. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
addition, the Company has purchase commitments related to the Kittila Mine for oxygen and electricity supplies: </FONT></P>
</UL>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (thousands of United States dollars, except per share amounts, unless otherwise indicated)<BR>
December 31, 2009 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 13.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;LEASES  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>(a)</I></B></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>Capital Leases</I></B></FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
2009, the Company entered into five sale-leaseback agreements with third-parties for various fixed and mobile equipment within Canada. These arrangements represent
sale-leaseback transactions in accordance with ASC 840-40&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Sale-Leaseback Transactions. The following table provides summarized information related
to these transactions: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>All
of the sale-leaseback agreements have end of lease clauses that qualify as bargain purchase options that the Company expects to execute. The total gross amount of assets recorded under
sales-leaseback capital leases amount to $21.0&nbsp;million (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;nil). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company has agreements with third-party providers of mobile equipment for the development of the Meadowbank Mine and the Kittila Mine. These arrangements represent capital leases in accordance
with the guidance in ASC&nbsp;840-30&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Capital Leases. The leases for mobile equipment at the Kittila Mine are for five years and the leases for mobile
equipment at the Meadowbank Mine are for three years. The effective annual interest rate on the lease for mobile equipment at Meadowbank is 3.15%. The effective annual interest rate on the lease for
mobile equipment at Kittila is&nbsp;4.99%. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
following is a schedule of future minimum lease payments under capital leases together with the present value of the net minimum lease payments as at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2009. </FONT></P>
</UL>
</UL>

<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

<!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS END --></TR>

<TH style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH NOWRAP  ALIGN="LEFT" style="font-family:times;"><DIV style="border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;width:89pt;"><FONT SIZE=1><B>Year ending December&nbsp;31:

the end of 2009, the gross amount of assets recorded under capital leases, including sale-leaseback capital leases was $51.7&nbsp;million

December 31, 2009 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 13.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;LEASES (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>(b)</I></B></FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B><I>Operating Leases</I></B></FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company has a number of operating lease agreements involving office space. Some of the leases for office facilities contain escalation clauses for increases in operating costs and property taxes.
Future minimum lease payments required to meet obligations that have initial or remaining non-cancellable lease terms in excess of one year as at December&nbsp;31, 2009 are
as&nbsp;follows: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Total
rental expense for operating leases was $3.7&nbsp;million in 2009 (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$3.1&nbsp;million;
2007&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$1.4&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

</UL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 14.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;RESTRICTED CASH  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
2008, the Company raised approximately $43.5&nbsp;million through the issuance of 779,250&nbsp;flow-through common shares. To comply with the flow-through share
agreements, the Company was obligated to incur $31&nbsp;million of eligible Canadian exploration expenditures in 2009 related to the expenditures renounced in 2008 (note&nbsp;6(b)). The amount of
cash the Company was obligated to spend was designated as restricted cash as at December&nbsp;31, 2008. In 2009, the Company incurred the full amount of its Canadian exploration expenditures
obligation required under the flow-through share agreements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
2009, the Company raised approximately $25.9&nbsp;million through the issuance of 358,900&nbsp;flow-through common shares. By December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company had incurred all
required expenditures on eligible Canadian exploration expenditures related to the 2009 flow-through common share issuance (note&nbsp;6(b)) and&nbsp;the balance of restricted cash was&nbsp;nil
at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2009. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 15.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>From
time to time, Agnico-Eagle has entered into financial instruments with a number of financial institutions in order to hedge underlying cash flow and fair value exposures arising from changes in
commodity prices, interest rates, equity prices or foreign currency exchange&nbsp;rates. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
2008 and 2009, financial instruments which have subjected Agnico-Eagle to market risk and concentration of credit risk consisted primarily of cash, cash equivalents and short-term
investments. Agnico-Eagle places its cash and cash equivalents and
short-term investments in high quality securities issued by government agencies, financial institutions and major corporations and limits the amount of credit exposure by diversifying
its&nbsp;holdings. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Agnico-Eagle
generates almost all of its revenues in US dollars. The Company's Canadian operations, which include the LaRonde Mine, the Goldex Mine, the Lapa Mine, and the Meadowbank Mine, have
Canadian dollar requirements for capital, operating and exploration expenditures. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
2008, to mitigate the risks associated with fluctuating foreign exchange rates, the Company entered into three zero cost collars to hedge the functional currency equivalent cash flows associated
with the Canadian dollar denominated capital expenditures related to the Meadowbank Mine. In March&nbsp;2009, the Company entered into another zero cost collar for the same purpose. The purchase of
US&nbsp;dollar put options has been financed through selling US dollar call options at a higher level such that the net premium payable to the different counterparties by the Company is nil. The
hedged items represents monthly unhedged forecast Canadian dollar cash outflows during 2009. At December&nbsp;31, 2008, the three zero cost collars hedged $180&nbsp;million of 2009 expenditures
and the additional zero cost collar entered in 2009 hedged $45&nbsp;million of 2009 expenditures. The cash flow hedging relationship meets all requirements per ASC&nbsp;815 to be perfectly
effective, and unrealized gains and losses is recognized within other comprehensive income ("OCI"). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Gains
and losses deferred in accumulated other comprehensive income ("AOCI") are recognized into income as amortization (or&nbsp;depreciation) of the hedged capital asset occurs. Amounts transferred
out of accumulated OCI are recorded in the Property, Plant and Mine development line item in the balance sheet and are amortized into income over the same period as the hedged capital asset. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (thousands of United States dollars, except per share amounts, unless otherwise indicated)<BR>
December 31, 2009 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 15.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
2009, all of the effective hedges matured and a total of $7.4&nbsp;million was reclassified from OCI to the balance sheet as a credit to Property, Plant, and mine development line item. The total
amount of unrealized loss on the hedges was nil as at December&nbsp;31, 2009 (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$8.9&nbsp;million). The Company expects approximately $0.6&nbsp;million
to be reclassified into earnings in&nbsp;2010 as the net gain is amortized in relation to the hedged capital asset. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
following table shows the changes in the AOCI balances recorded in the consolidated financial statements pertaining to the foreign exchange hedging activities. The fair values, based on
Black-Scholes calculated mark-to-market valuations, of recorded derivative related assets and liabilities and their corresponding entries to AOCI reflect the netting of the
fair values of individual derivative financial instruments. </FONT></P>
</UL>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>As
at December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company had unmatured covered call options on available-for-sale securities with a premium of $1.1&nbsp;million
(2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$3.1&nbsp;million) and a Black-Scholes calculated mark-to-market gain (loss) of $0.5&nbsp;million
(2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$(0.8) million). Premiums received on the sale of covered call options are recorded as a liability in the fair value of derivative financial instrument
component of the consolidated balance sheets until they mature or the position is closed. Gains or losses as a result of mark-to-market valuations are taken into income in the
period incurred. The Company sold these call options against the shares and warrants of Goldcorp&nbsp;Inc. ("Goldcorp") to reduce its price exposure to the Goldcorp shares and warrants it acquired
in connection with Goldcorp's acquisition of Gold Eagle Mines&nbsp;Ltd. During 2009, the Company continued to write covered call options on the shares and warrants of Goldcorp as they expire and/or
were repurchased. The amount of $0.6&nbsp;million (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;3.9&nbsp;million) recorded as a liability as at December&nbsp;31, 2009, is expected to be
recognized through the consolidated statements of income in&nbsp;2010. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>During
the year-ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company recognized a net gain of $10.5&nbsp;million (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$(0.8) million) in the interest and
sundry income component of the consolidated statements of income related to the written call options of Goldcorp shares and&nbsp;warrants. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>During
the third quarter of 2009, the Company sold its 0.8&nbsp;million shares of Goldcorp shares but continued to write call options on the 0.8&nbsp;million warrants it continues to hold. Cash
provided by operating activities in the consolidated statements of cash flows are adjusted for gains realized on the consolidated statements of income through the loss (gain) on sale of securities
component. Premiums received are a component of proceeds on sale of available-for-sale securities and other within the cash used in investing activities section of the
consolidated statements of cash&nbsp;flows. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>As
at December&nbsp;31, 2009 and 2008, there were no metal derivative positions. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Other
required derivative disclosures can be found in note&nbsp;6(f), "Accumulated other comprehensive income (loss)". </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Agnico-Eagle's
exposure to interest rate risk at December&nbsp;31, 2009 relates to its cash and cash equivalents, short-term investments and restricted cash totalling
$163.6&nbsp;million (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$99.4&nbsp;million) and its credit facilities. The Company's short-term investments and cash equivalents have a fixed
weighted average interest rate of 0.59% (2008&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;3.21%). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
fair values of Agnico-Eagle's current financial assets and liabilities approximate their carrying values as at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
September&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued ASC 820&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Fair Value Measurement and Disclosure (Prior authoritative literature: FASB Statement No.&nbsp;157, "Fair
Value Measurements" ("FAS&nbsp;157")). ASC&nbsp;820 defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value in US&nbsp;GAAP, and expands required disclosures about fair value
measurements. The provisions of ASC&nbsp;820 were adopted January&nbsp;1, 2008. In February&nbsp;2008, FASB modified ASC 820 (Prior authoritative literature: FASB Staff Position
No.&nbsp;157-2, "Effective Date of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;157" that&nbsp;delayed the effective date of ASC&nbsp;820 for nonfinancial assets and nonfinancial liabilities, except
for items that are recognized or disclosed at fair value in the financial statements on a recurring basis (at&nbsp;least annually). The new provisions of ASC&nbsp;820 were effective for the
Company's fiscal year beginning January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Fair
value is the value at which a financial instrument could be closed out or sold in a transaction with a willing and knowledgeable counterparty over a period of time consistent with the Company's
investment strategy. Fair value is based on quoted market prices, </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>35</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=17,SEQ=35,EFW="2197667",CP="AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED",DN="4",CHK=781833,FOLIO='35',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAH3.10ZAH79303]FI79303B.;68',USER='JDAY',CD='26-MAR-2010;15:10' -->
<A NAME="page_fi79303_1_36"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (thousands of United States dollars, except per share amounts, unless otherwise indicated)<BR>
December 31, 2009 </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 15.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<UL>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>where
available. If market quotes are not available, fair value is based on internally developed models that use market-based or independent information as inputs. These models could produce a fair
value that may not be reflective of future fair&nbsp;value. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
three levels of the fair value hierarchy under ASC&nbsp;820 are: </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Level&nbsp;1&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Unadjusted
quoted prices in active markets that are accessible at the measurement date for identical, unrestricted assets or&nbsp;liabilities; </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Level&nbsp;2&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Quoted
prices in markets that are not active, or inputs that are observable, either directly or indirectly, for substantially the full term of
the asset or liability;&nbsp;and </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Level&nbsp;3&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Prices
or&nbsp;valuation techniques that require inputs that are both significant to the fair value measurement and unobservable (supported by
little or no market activity). </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
following table sets out the Company's financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value within the fair value hierarchy. </FONT></P>
</UL>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="12%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="12%" ALIGN="LEFT" >


<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Fair
value approximates the carrying amounts due to the short-term nature.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(2)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Recorded
at fair value using quoted market prices.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(3)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Recorded
at fair value based on broker-dealer quotations.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(4)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Assets
for the defined benefit pension plan consists of deposits on hand with regulatory authorities which are refundable when benefit payments are made or
on the ultimate wind-up of the plan.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(5)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Recorded
at cost. This line item also includes accrued interest. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Cash
equivalents and short-term investments are classified as Level&nbsp;2 of the fair value hierarchy because they are held to maturity and valued using interest rates observable at commonly quoted
intervals. Cash equivalents are market securities with remaining maturities of three months or less at the date of&nbsp;purchase. The short-term investments are market securities with remaining
maturities of over three months at the date of purchase. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company's available-for-sale equity securities valued using quoted market prices in active markets are classified as Level&nbsp;1 of the fair value hierarchy. The fair
value of these securities are calculated as the quoted market price of the security multiplied by the quantity of shares held by the&nbsp;Company. The Company's
available-for-sale securities classified as Level&nbsp;2 of the fair value hierarchy consist of equity warrants. The fair value of these Level&nbsp;2 securities are
calculated based on the broker-dealer quotation multiplied by the quantity of equity warrants held by the&nbsp;Company. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
the event that a decline in the fair value of an investment occurs and the decline in value is considered to be other-than-temporary, an impairment charge is recorded in the
consolidated statement of income and a new cost basis for the investment is established. The Company assesses whether a decline in value is considered to be
other-than-temporary by considering available evidence, including </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>36</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=18,SEQ=36,EFW="2197667",CP="AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED",DN="4",CHK=26375,FOLIO='36',FILE='DISK122:[10ZAH3.10ZAH79303]FI79303B.;68',USER='JDAY',CD='26-MAR-2010;15:10' -->
<A NAME="page_fi79303_1_37"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (thousands of United States dollars, except per share amounts, unless otherwise indicated)<BR>
December 31, 2009 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 15.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<UL>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>changes
in general market conditions, specific industry and individual company data, the length of time and the extent to which the fair value has been less than cost, the financial condition and the
near-term prospects of the individual investment. New evidence could become available in future periods which would affect this assessment and thus could result in material impairment
charges with respect to those investments for which the cost basis exceeds its fair&nbsp;value. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 16.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SEGMENTED INFORMATION  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Agnico-Eagle
predominantly operates in a single industry, namely exploration for and production of gold. Based on the internal reporting structure and the nature of the Company's activities, the
Company identifies its reportable segments as those consolidated mining operations or functional groups that represent more than 10% of the combined revenue, profit or loss or total assets of all
reported operating segments. Consolidated mining operations or functional groups not meeting this threshold are aggregated at the applicable geographic region for segment reporting purposes. This
structure reflects how the Company manages its business and how it classifies its operations for planning and measuring performance: </FONT></P>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Corporate
Head Office assets are included in the Canada category and specific corporate income and expense items are noted separately below. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>On
May&nbsp;1, 2009, both the Lapa Mine and Kittila Mine achieved commercial production. The Pinos Altos Mine achieved commercial production on November&nbsp;1, 2009. The Goldex Mine achieved
commercial production August&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2008. The Meadowbank Mine is expected to achieve commercial production in the first quarter of 2010. </FONT></P>
